description: The mass extermination of the Mongol Dzungar people by the Qing dynasty, ordered by the Qianlong Emperor following a rebellion led by Dzungar leader Amursana.

cause.initial: Rebellion in 1755 by Dzungar leader Amursana against Qing rule
cause.support: Manchu generals of the Qing army, supported by Turkic oasis dwellers

Battle_of_Oroi-Jalatu.description: Chinese general Zhao Hui attacked the Dzungar camp at night, in present Wusu, Xinjiang

demographic_changes_post_genocide.resettlement: Millions of ethnic Han Chinese, Hui, Central Asian oasis people (Uyghurs), and Manchu Bannermen in Dzungaria

cultural_and_political_impact.promotion_of_Islam: Crushing of the Buddhist Öölöd (Dzungars) led to the promotion of Islam and the empowerment of Muslim Begs in southern Xinjiang
cultural_and_political_impact.Qing_naming: Qing named the conquered territory Xinjiang and converted steppe grassland to farmland
cultural_and_political_impact.demographic_distribution: 62% Uyghurs in the south, 30% Han and Hui in the north, and 8% various other minorities in Xinjiang during Qing period

scholarly_views.Henry_Schwarz: Proposed that the Qing victory was, in a certain sense, a victory for Islam
scholarly_views.James_A_Millward: Pointed out Qing agricultural colonies had nothing to do with Uyghurs and their land, directed Han settlers to non-Uyghur Dzungaria and Ürümqi

references.Perdue_2005: Chapters 3–7 describe the rise and fall of the Dzungar Khanate
